ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: First half of the course operated like any upper-level seminar, assuming some background knowledge and focusing on different topics each week.

I developed a more nuanced understanding of Human Rights. We were able to study and critique the field from different angles artistic, political, legal, personal. I appreciated learning and observing how these different perspectives lended to one another.

This was a really nice course during COVID, getting to be with the Human Rights community in some form was really comforting and despite the online format, it was a really productive space to discuss capstones and wrap up the themes of the program

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Jim and Paul are both incredible instructors. They set up great discussions and are incredibly generous with their time, even in a global pandemic. However, the capstone was less enjoyable than other interactions we've had with Jim and Paul (including weekly discussions for a year of the MAPHR cohort experience) in large part because no one put their foot down when certain students attempted to derail the conversation. A few students would consistently show disrespect for their classmates while these classmates were speaking by spamming the Zoom chat with entirely different topics. This dynamic, which was emboldened each week that no professor said anything about it, contributed to derailing conversations and divesting me from the work. The course is still great. I enjoyed my time in it and anyone who has the opportunity to complete the MAPHR sequence should do it. However, changing this dynamic could improve future years.

I loved how we studied different critiques of Human Rights for the first half of the course. The conversations we had in this first half of the course gave us a foundation on which to understand, appreciate, and workshop other peoples capstone projects in the second half of the course.

I really enjoyed the last readings, but they also did feel a little repetitive as a summary of some of the things that we had already discussed and learned about in HMRT 100. Obviously the class needed it to be classified as a credit, but I think this would overall be more productive and people would be more engaged in discussion with some different or more specific topics.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really think this was the best we could do in this time; this class already has a good community so I think it translated well into an online format

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Required for the Human Rights program so yes, but also the capstone is really the best part of the program because it uses everything you have learned in a cumulative way.
